repnme.cdata!: China - Forestry Development in Poor Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Forestry Development in
            Poor Areas Project for China were as follows: the outcome
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was highly likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: Farmer participation and
            empowerment through Community Forest Assessment was an
            appropriate project innovation that helped to ensure that
            social objectives were achieved. A strong
            research-extension-training linkage was fundamental to
            transferring new production techniques/technologies and
            management to farmers/foresters. The development of a
            fertilizer market implies that farmers can obtain fertilizer
            more efficiently than through central procurement and
            distribution. Future projects should include fertilizer
            costs in farmers' loan packages. The participatory
            approach is effective in ensuring farmers/foresters feel a
            sense of ownership, but very poor farmers/foresters must be
            cautioned that planting timber species could result in loan
            repayment difficulties as maturity and harvest are long
            term. Intensive and detailed Township and Village Enterprise
            (TVE) analyses are necessary for projects with TVE
            on-lending components. Manufacturing enterprises are more
            susceptible to market shifts than producers of raw materials
            and therefore requires critical evaluation.

repnme.cdata!: China - Forestry Development in Poor Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Forestry
            Development in Poor Areas Project is to develop forest
            resources in poor areas of central and western China on a
            sustainable and participatory basis to support poverty
            reduction, forestry development, and improved environmental
            management.  The project components include the
            establishment of timber plantations and economic forest
            crops, including bamboo, fruit, nut and medicinal trees.
            The technical support services components include: (a) a
            planting stock development program; (b) a training and
            extension program; (c) a rural infrastructure program; and
            (d) a monitoring and evaluation program.  The Township and
            Village Enterprises (TVE) component will provide sub-loans
            to support the development of small-scale, labor-intensive,
            commercially oriented Tees in the forestry sector, such as
            pine resin extraction, bamboo processing, wicker  works,
            edible forest product processing, and parquet and veneer production.
